text: Bottle; pours dark brown with a beige head; aroma of caramel, bourbon, dark fruits, and some wood notes; taste is sweet with caramel, dark fruits, vanilla, and hints of toffee and wood; dry finish with some light warming
Bomber shared at tasting. Dark brown caramel pour. Boozy aroma, caramel, chocolate. Taste follows, a little hot for me. Still really good.
Dark brown pour with a slight head. Nose is malty with a hit of oak and bourbon. Lots of bourbon with malt and some heat on the finish.

Copper-amber color with a bit of white head. Sweet boozy malty and caramel aromas. Fairly sweet yet not aggressive, a straight forward yet perfectly balanced barleywine with a moderate and complementary oak character. Really an outstanding barleywine. 

Notes: on tap at the brewery during our May 17 Anchorage visit.

Shared bomber poured to snifters displaying a clear, deep amber hue, with a presentable layer of off white froth that reduced to a ring & light film, with foamy spots of lacing. The nose was malty sweet, candied & dried fruit, subtle spice, with some barrel hints and vanilla. The taste was similar but more expressive notes, medium+ bodied, with mild carbonation, bourbony booze & warmth, and a finishing, tannic dryness. Very solid BW.

Pours a hazy brown with very little head from a bottle. Big raisiny and oaky aroma follows into the mouth, where a nice vanilla and almost an irish creme note come out. Boozy, I bet it ages nicely for a year. Pretty good beer.

Bottle 
Pours murky hazy orange hue with barely any head. Nose is musty vanilla dark fruit. Flavors are big vanilla dark fruits. Lots of vanilla and woody notes. Long big dark fruits on the finish. Alcohol heat is low for the abv. Excellent brew!

Draught at City Beer SF. Hazy light brown color, white head. Bitter taste with citrus, dried fruit, hops, ripe fruits, nuts, toffee, caramel and a bit of alcohol. Bitter finish with citrus, toffee, dried fruits, ripe fruits, resin, nuts, a bit of alcohol and caramel. Excellent barley wine.

Type: 22-oz. bottle
Glass: AleSmith Barrel-Aged Reserve snifter
From: Bine & Vine Bottle Shop in Normal Heights (San Diego), Calif. 
Price: $17.99 
Purchased: Jan. 6, 2017
Consumed: April 15, 2017
Reviewed as: English Barleywine
Misc.: Bottled on Nov. 21, 2016

Picked this up with basically a $50 gift certificate for my birthday. Had heard of Midnight Sun and saw on one of the emails that they had a few coming in, so I pounced on this and the Berserker Imperial Stout. $19.99 (Berserker) and $17.99 (AD) seems a bit much but I got them anyway. Gave Berserker an overrated 4.16 (93/A-) back in January. Hoping for this to be better. 

Poured a copper/garnet cloudy color with one finger of khaki white frothy head. Some light bubble streams coming up from the bottom of the glass. Good spotty lacing. Good retention. (Sight - 3.75)

Smelled pent up bourbon, almost port wine like, dark fruits, plum, tobacco, raisins, sticky toffee, caramel, brown sugar, maple syrup, some oaky red wine barrels and earthy basement aromas. Lovely. (Smell - 4.50)

Taste was at least just as good as the nose. Wow. Lots going on. Got smooth bourbon, port wine, sherry red wine, tobacco, unknown lingering spices (rye? maybe pepper?), brown sugar, maple syrup, toffee, plum, dark fruits, raisins, dates, prunes, dark grainy malts, caramel, smooth, but tasting the booze, oak, hints of molasses and sticky sugary chocolate syrup which seems to be muted somewhat by everything else going on. (Taste - 4.25)

Medium body. Sticky texture. Average carbonation. Long, smooth finish. (Feel - 5.00)

This was fantastic. Much better than I thought it was going to be after having Berserker a few months back. Would not pay $18 for this again, but still delicious. (Overall - 4.50)

4.41 98 A
Tap at Harrys Hofbrau in Redwood City. Maple colored and clear with almost no head. Sugary and cloying. Moderate crystal malt.

This is sorta my white whale. Theyve cut back their distribution in Oregon and Im sad. Rich, sweet (but pleasantly so), a perfect execution of an English Barleywine. Plums and figs dominate, but a minor hop presence lets you know your drinking beer. Cellars so well and improves for years.
Smells nicely of molasses. The flavor is thick and chewy. Quite good. The only real downside to this is that its a bit too sweet. Otherwise solid beer.

2011 bottle, from a 2012 IP trade with Richiesd (thanks!) so about time this got cracked. Dark brown color with a red hue. Off white head with short retention. Aromas: bourbon, vanilla, sweetness, caramel, treacle, light fruit, alcohol. Retronasal theres treacle, molasses, bourbon, vanilla, toffee. Flavor is quite sweet, light fruity, alcoholic. Alcohol feel is a bit strong and sharp. Medium bodied. Long finish, with alcohol and a bit fruit.

At the Barleywine event. Aroma is caramel, toffee, slight hop, barrel, bourbon. Appearance is amber brown, light tan head, clear. Taste is caramel, bourbon, barrel, toffee, dark fruit, right. Mouthfeel is medium to heavy body, light carbonation, caramel toffee barrel aftertaste. Overall, very good.
From a 22 oz. bottler it is a clear Amber color with an ecru head. The Aroma is of toffee and caramel.and the taste is sweet licorice and hints og bourbon. The finish is Sweet and flavorful.y
From a 22 oz. bottle. Pours a clear amber with an ecru head. Aroma of toffee and caramel. Flavors of oak and bourbon. Sweet and flavorful.

wasnt liking the style so let this sit for awhile; thanks to a great rber for the trade; guessing this is a2013 bottle (says aged in bourbon oak barrels). much like a quad - dark fruits and caramel in aroma and taste. neither bourbon nor alcohol were that prevalent. smooth, sweetness balanced well.
22oz. Murky brown. Caramel and toffee. Very oaky. Touch of bourbon. Slight nutty. Very smooth finish. Hides the ABV very well.

Shared a 22oz bottle.

Boozy, stone fruit aroma; caramel toffee syrupy taste and mouthfeel. Alchohol present but not harsh. Nice oaky flavor as well.

This beer is strong as hell. You expect that from a barleywine and from a beer that's 13.4% ABV, but this is strong behind that. I smell raisins and taste them too, and while it's nice to sip, it's just a little too overpowering to love.
Tap at Bambinos. Murky deep amber pour with a tight white head. Rich caramel, wood, port, whiskey - great depth of aromatics and taste. Awesome.

A fantastic barleywine, tastes very well refined yet complex. Pours a beautiful deep red with a small amount of tan head. Smells of bourbon, caramel, strawberry and cherry, dark fruits. Smells as well as tastes more like a quad then a barleywine. Taste has lots of dark fruit and carmelized walnuts, vanilla, followed by an amazingly smooth finish topped with a bourbon smokiness and lingering booze. Our favorite barleywine. Had in the bottle.

Draft at Beer Authority, Seattle. Tight creamy tan foam on velvety rich brown. Sticky, barrel notes, dark fruit. Exceptionally balanced, clean sharp flavors. Raisin, molasses, cherry pit, leather. Vanilla hints. Strong, rich, good all warming. Delicious.

Sampled at a tasting. Dark amber pour, thin tan head. Smells like bourbon, dark cherries, green hops and vanilla. Tastes like cherries, bourbon, almonds, alcohol, vanilla, toasted coconut, caramel, maple syrup. Medium body and a medium-low carbonation. Bitter-sweet aftertaste. An excellent barleywine.

Murky dark amber color with beige head. Aroma is really fruity with caramel and bourbon. Taste starts sweet, fruity with caramel, toasted malts and bourbon. Body is syrupy and well carbonated. Really nice overall, sweet, fruity and the ABV is well hidden.

On tap. 2013 vintage. Pours a dark reddish brown with light persistent head. Aromas of bready malts and caramel. Flavors of rich brown sugar, toffee, sweet malts and light grassy hops. No trace of bourbon but very nice. Full and sweet.

Bottle gift from Knacks. Booze, wood,roasted malts, caramel, raisin and toffee are the dominant flavors. Slight burn as it goes down. Pretty darn good. The aroma smelled a little like tin. 94 to go until retirement.

Draught at the brewery. Pours clear tawny with a medium, frothy off-white head, short retention with light lacing. Aroma is alcohol, bready and honey malt, citrus and pine hops with bananas. Flavor is brown sugar, bready and honey malt, pear and banana esters, spicy alcohol and a dry finish. Full body and medium carbonation.
If I liked barley wines I might rate this higher. Barrel aging probably helps take some of the bite out which I like.

December 24, 2015 - bottle via trade and opened as part of my dancin with the devil night. Brown pour with some head and foamed up nicely with a gentle swirl. Aroma was sweet malt, dark fruit and bourbon. Taste was nicely balanced with the sweetness, fruit and heat.
Bottle to snifter. Huge dark malt, rich, lots of melanoidin and dark fruit.ight vanilla. Dark brown pour with ruby highlights. Taste is sticky sweet. Moderate dark fruit as well. Nice

Dark opaque brown, thin sticky limber of a head. Nose is gritty caramel, sawdusty choc. Initial taste is gloopy choc, blackberry and lean dark pepper. Soft and sticky mouthfeel. Finishes clean dark berry and dark roastiness and lingers out as a rich sweetness.

Bottle thanks to sir Mike of Wright. Near black with little to no head. Aroma is heavily oxodised, sherry, dried fruit, prunes, raisins, dates. Taste is similar, sherry, dried fruits, prunes, raisins. Sweet. Delish
Bottle at the 1st Annual Christmas at The Garvies tasting 2015. Pours black with a thin tan head. Aromas of chocolate, vanilla, coffee. Taste is boozy, light sweet chocolate finish.
Pours deep black with a slight brown head. Aroma is roasty, nutty and caramelly. Taste is earrthy, caramel, slight hop bitter, smooth cocoa. Full bodied. Big thanks to BenH!

Bottle at home ... christmas 2015 tasting ... dark brown ... thin tan lacing ... soft sweet toffee malts .. soft toffee malt nose ... soft sweet malts ... soft sweet berries .. soft toffee .. dark roast .. sweet berries soft sweet malts ..
Bottle at craigs. Pours black, nose is toffee, chocolate, cacao, taste is similar, sweet, chocolate, toffee.

2011 bottle. Pours a dark mahogany murky thin khaki soapy head that settles to a wispy film and sudsy collar. Aroma is sweet burnt caramel malt soft faded wood and leather. Taste is faded brunt caramel oak English malt with lingering wood chips.... Possible oxidation. Whiskey oak wood very mild and hidden, aroma is still nice as well as taste, but showing the 4 years.
22oz bottle. Cloudy ruddy brown hue. Musty old malt/dried fruit nose. Caramel & aged stone fruit flavor w/oxidization hints. Full bodied, medium- carbonation.

Enjoyed at an all barley wine tasting at Traviss house on February 21. 22 oz bottle, 2011 vintage. The pour is a nice dark ruby with a thinner light tan head ans minimal lacing. The aroma is really big on dark fruits. Specifically raisins and figs. There is also a strong roasted maltiness, caramel, and toffee. There is a surprising amount of booze on the back end. The flavor is a little boozy up front. The dark fruits and malt really move through the back end. The mouth feel is thick and viscous, and perfectly carbonated. The aftertaste is lingeringly boozy with great fruit and toffee traces.

Aroma: caramel, alcohol, toffee, grain malts. Appearance: hazy, dark brown, small, white head. Taste: heavy sweet. Palate: sweets expand, caramel, molasses, sugars, alcohol, full body, flat carbonation. Overall: excellent Barley Wine, great aroma and taste. Bottle from the brewery, Anchorage.

Shared 2013 vintage at Craft. Hazy copper pour with off-white head. Nose was caramel malt, hops, oaky bourbon, molasses, Tastes caramel malty rich on the tongue, with spare hops, oak, bourbon, and a dense, complex finish.
30 may 2015, bottle. Amber and a tad hazy. Nose is sweet, malty, boozy, just like a barley wine should smell. Ned body and moderately fizzy. Sweet, brown sugar malt. Nice.
Pours a dark amber color with a white head. Oak, alcohol, caramel, chocolate, toffee, hop and toast aroma and flavors. Full body and average carbonation. Alcohol, caramel and hop finish. 2011
Bomber poured into a tulip glass..chestnut color with fluffy off white head..aroma of booze,caramel,toffee,molasses..surprisingly smooth,not overly boozy for a 13%er..excellent.

22 oz bottle. Deep Amber with a decent sized beige head. Aroma is of booze, toffee, caramel, oak, vanilla, toast, some leather, buttery pie crust. Taste is of oak, vanilla, toffee cake, raisin, booze, caramel, and oatmeal cookies.

Bottle. The look is reddish to brown in color, beige colored head, and clear. The smell is boozy, fruit, toffee, caramel, wood, bourbon, and awesome. The taste is complex, alcohol, fruit, brown sugar, caramel, wood, and great.
Drank during the tasting 08-05. Much carbonation that masks the taste. Okay sweetness but not that special.
Bottle. Caramel, toffee, brown sugar, vanilla, cinnamon, booze, a little sweet, extremely smooth. Absolutely awesome. Complete home run. I want more.

Bottle. Dark brown pour with little head. Initial sip gives off a stinging oaky burn akin to bourbon, but things settle down from there. Caramel, toffee, oak, brown sugar, cinnamon raisin bread and light vanilla come together in nice proportion to keep the booze in check and make this a well-layered sipper. Big chewy mouthfeel. This is one of the tastiest beers Ive ever drank.
Bottle. Pours a brownish amber with minimal beige head. Aroma of booze and oak up front, some caramel too. Taste of caramel, oak, with some booze on the back end.

Bottle shared by jheath99. Pours murky brown with beige head. Aroma is caramel, bready and cookie malts, leather, oak, vanilla, and faint dates. Flavor is sweet nd chewy malt profile with a decent amount of hop bitterness to keep things from being cloying along with some nice barrel character that doesnt bring along too much hard alcohol, but it does have a sweet, boozy finish. Medium/full body.

Draft pour at the Brouwers hard liver festival. 2013 edition. From notes. Pours a reddish brown color with a swirling foam head. Wet, sweet malt aroma. Sweet and spicy flavor with some cinnamon. A little dry on the finish. Overall very tasty. Enjoyed this.

March 17, 2015. Bottle at home, vintage 2013. Received in a trade with Countbeer, thanks Kamiel!
Hazy reddish brown with a minimal white head. Aroma is figs, raisins, dark sugars, bourbon, caramel. Taste is sweet with dried fruits, dark sugars, bourbon, vanilla, alcohol. Finish is very light bitter and dominated by sweet dried fruits, vanilla, bourbon, oak and caramel. Medium to full bodied, soft carbonation.

[2/15/15] Draught at Toronado in San Francisco. Reddish brown with a beige head. Nice aroma of malt, dark fruits, caramel, hops, a bit of cookies and a bit of alcohol. Sweet flavor with malt, caramel, some cookies, fruitiness, a chocolate note, some hops and a mild to moderate boozy finish. Full-bodied. A good one.

Bottle served in a snifter. 2013 vintage. 13.4%, 20 IBUs. Pours dark brown with a short tan head that settles to a light film. Nose is sweet and malty with vanilla, nut, toffee, and melted caramel accents. Not overpowering considering the ABV. Medium-plus sweet attack followed by a snappy bitterness. Full body, ultra-creamy texture, minimal carbonation, and a long, bitter, warming finish. Seems to have more in the neighborhood of 50 IBUs.

Bottle shared at the Commons, big thanks to Jason IIRC, 09/11/14.
Chestnut brown with a beige covering.
Nose is dark fruit peel, toffee, spice, woody notes.
Taste comprises rich dark fruits, cake mix, spice, brown sugar, sweet licks, sticky toffee pudding, subtle bourbon notes.
Full bodied, fine carbonation, lightly warming alcohol.
Decent barley wine, perhaps a notch or two less than expected for me, but solid sipping juice and drinks below the ABV.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: UPDATED: MAR 7, 2015 3000th review! 22 ounce bottle into snifter; 2014 vintage, bottled in late 2013. Pours hazy dark ruby red color with a 1 finger fairly dense khaki head with solid retention, that reduces to a small spotty lace cap that lingers. Slight spotty lacing on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big raisin, plum, fig, caramel, toffee, toast, brown sugar, coconut, vanilla, bourbon, oak, leather, light chocolate, and oak/toasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/toasted malt, fruity yeast, and bourbon barrel notes; with good strength. Light-moderate booziness as it warms, but not too bad. Taste of big raisin, plum, fig, caramel, toffee, butterscotch, toast, coconut, brown sugar, molasses, brown bread, bourbon, oak, vanilla, leather, light chocolate, and oak/toasted earthiness. Light oaky bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of raisin, plum, fig, caramel, butterscotch, molasses, toffee, toast, coconut, vanilla, brown sugar, bourbon, oak, leather, light chocolate, and oak/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Incredible complexity and robustness of dark/bready malt, fruity yeast, and bourbon barrel flavors; with an awesome malt/yeast/barrel balance and zero cloying sweetness after the finish. Light carbonation and fairly full bodied; with a very creamy, fairly slick, and slightly syrupy/sticky mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is well hidden with only a light-moderate warming lingering after the finish. Overall this is a fantastic barrel aged English barelywine style. All around awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malt, fruity yeast, and bourbon barrel flavors; and smooth to sip on for the huge ABV. A highly enjoyable offering.
Bottle. Brown color with solid white head. Thick toasted toffee and woody aroma. Taste boozy lots of caramel with a slight bitter hop.

Bottle: 2007 vintage. Thanks, Ed. Was a little over 5 years old at the time of opening. Dark mahogany color with a brash haziness. A thin, light-tan layer of foam evades the top & quickly forms a tiny ring. Good to see any sign of carbonation at all, really. Aroma loaded with oak, bourbon, sweet plums, black cherries, light maple syrup, brown sugar, & molasses. Very sweet, very complex. Malty dimepiece. No signs of oxidation in the aroma OR in the flavor. Thick, muddled, heavy body. Very strong sweetness, albeit controlled & refined. Dark brown sugar, molasses, maple, anise, plums, dates, red grapes, black cherries, buttery toffee, light vanilla, &a robust helping of alcohol. Finished & lingers with candied dark fruits, sticky caramel, & oak. Warming, but not hot. Sweet, but not cloying. Delicious & woody. Great barley wine. 
Bottle: 2011 vintage thanks to Mike. A little over 3 years old. A lovely barley wine all around, as expected. A little more carbonation & actually a slightly thinner mouth feel than I remember. Heavier bourbon flavor, lots of anise & bourbon with a large oak & toffee presence. Heavy dark fruits, as usual, too. Prefer the older vintage but this was still great.
Bottle: 2013 vintage, thanks to Steve. Somewhere between 1 to 2 years old. Much smoother than expected. Boozy, sure, but not abrasive at all. Super sticky sweet, probably the heaviest with butter toffee, caramel, & brown sugar. Lovely oak finish. Once again, great stuff.

Bottle. 2008 vintage. Pours a deep, deep cooper color with a slight ringed tan head. Caramel notes abound. Medium/heavy mouthfeel. Caramel and butterscotch flavors with a hint of bitterness in the back end. warms very nicel.
Bottle..Pour is golden with a faded head..Nose is spice, sweet, bourbon, sweet..Taste is spice, sweetness, bourbon, sticky, caramel. .

Medium brown with a pale head. Aroma is raisins, brown sugar, dates, maple. Full bodied, slightly sticky mouthfeel, sweet on the palate, lightly boozy finish. Taste is brown sugar, raisins, caramel, dates.
Bottle - Sweet vinous and caramel. Cloudy red copper with a decent beige head. Sweet caramel, raisin and a long finish. Really nice good example.

2013 bottle sampled Dec 19, 2014.

Bottle. After reading Prufrocks gloriously crunk review of Anchorage Deal with the Devil (Ive been there -- I love that feeling too!) I had to bust out my own 100/99 barrel aged Alaskan barleywine. Im very glad I did. At one year of age this has to be peaking. Im sure it needed a year, but it also clearly will not improve from here.

Pours a rich viscous sienna into my snifter with a small and ephemeral head. The nose: tons of vanilla and barleywine sweetness. Age on the hops, but only slight to hit that sweet spot between bitter bite and aged hop cheese. The bourbon is all vanilla and no booze. How do they do that? The flavor is warm and sweet, hops aged just right and bringing their bitterness only way after the finish and even then still dancing with the sugars. And all of that lovely vanilla oak. The palate is ridiculously smooth, basically zero heat. If it wasnt thick like a perfect ristretto Id think it was closer to 8% than 13+. Even so Id have called it at 10 or 11. This is pretty much a perfect BA barleywine. 
If I wanted to complain, Id have two avenues. The first is that Im bored of high alcohol beers. But thats a case of "Its not you, its me." The other much more damning complaint is that it doesnt have its own unique character. Its beautiful exactly the way that an average or composite of many womens faces is beautiful ( highbrow link: http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2435688/ ). But yeah, you know youd hit any of those --- so its pretty thin grounds on which to complain. 

tl;dr summary. Perfect BA barleywine. Yawn.

Bottle: Poured a deep dark cloudy brown color ale with a small dark brown foamy head with light retention and some minimal lacing. Aroma of toffee, residual brown sugar and caramelized malt is pretty awesome. Taste is also dominated by toffee with some brown sugar notes and caramelized malt. All rough edges have been rounded by the bourbon notes with light vanilla notes also noticeable. Body is full with limited filtration and a good amount of carbonation. This beer has so many layers of complexity while retaining such a good amount of drinkability. Really amazing beer that I wish I could try on a regular basis.

bottle thanks to jeff, shared with a friend. no notice of the vintage year, but im pretty sure it was a 2013 bottle... poured a murky light amber colour with a nice white head. toffee, caramel, lots of fruits in the nose, like plums, figs, rainsins, vanilla, got that sticky butter aroma, toasted malts, maybe some of a red fruit, there is a bourbon barrel notice, but not in a big amount that i would like in my barley wine. bit of a disappointment for such a high ranked beer. take some of the BA emelisse barley wines from the netherlands, it blews this one away in no time.

22 oz bottle gifted by AJax, thanks bud! 2013 vintage. Murky, dirty River water color without any type of head or retention. Aroma is oak, mild bourbon, sugar dipped raisins, caramel candy and vanilla.
The flavor has subtle bourbon with a moderate amount of oak. Sweet without being cloying. Warmth after the sip without the presence of alcohol taste. Syrupy sticky sweet texture in a fuller then medium in body. Pretty nice BBA barley wine.

Bottle vintage 2011; thanks Bruce! Pours a slightly hazy amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty spicy caramel woody aroma. Slightlyssweetish malty spicy caramel and dark fruit flavor. Has a sweetish malty dark fruit and caramel finish with woody hints.

Bottle: Thanks jdb288: Served in a Chouffe glass:
Hazy amber brown with a small creamy head.
Aromas of bourbon, caramel, raisin, cream, light liquor, some molasses, hints of butter and vanilla.
Flavours of bourbon, vanilla, malts, caramel, cream, bitters, light alcohol burn, wood, light molasses, some prunes and some raisin. Delicious!
Aftertaste malty, light bourbon and earthy tones, ending of cream, some caramel and wood.
Low carbo, oily silky mouthfeel, almost full bodied and a sticky texture.
Great aroma, good taste. Very fine beer!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Poured from bottle into scotch glass. Thin lingering head. Mouthfeel not as oily as others have described. Lively carb. Flavor is prototypical barley wine with intense butterscotch flavor that shapes the whole thing. bourbon barrel is smoothly integrated. Very smooth for the ABV. Well done

Bottle shared with the epic. Aroma of toffee, bourbon, malt, and caramel. Pours barleywine orange/brown and clear with nice carbonation and a small foamy head. Taste follows suit with vanilla, caramel, toffee, sweet chocolate, oak and bourbon. Mouthfeel is sweet without being too sticky intense. Just flawlessly executed. Immediately procured two more bottles.

"2010 bourbon barrel aged...boozy and complex. loads of vanilla from the barrels, dark malts, and bourbon in the aroma and flavor. slight hop presence barely noticed. delicious brew, if a bit overpriced at 17.99."

Bottle to glass. Pours a medium to deep brown color with a creamy tan head. Aroma is malty, boozy, vanilla, molasses. Flavor is bourbon, malt, booze, molasses. Medium body, thick oily mouthfeel. Phenomenal barleywine. Love the bourbon character.
Bottle at Goulets. Pours orange brown off white head. Nose/taste of bourbon, oak, vanilla, chewy malt, toffee. Full Bodied.

Bottle, thanks Eddan. 

Hazy brownish/orange with a medium head. Sweet with caramel, some warming alcohol, port wine and malt. A nice one to sip.

Draught. Pours a cloudy brown color with a smallish off white head on there. Nose has a lot of caramel and seems moderately boozy. Taste is a little sweet and the caramel is definitely there, as is some booze. Nice and smooth, though.

2011 bomber shared by my buddy Shem from his recently acquired stash of excellent aged beers. Pours a lovely garnet hue with only a thin layer of tan foam. Lovely AROMA of significant whiskey (rich not boozy), brown sugar, port wine, and candied cherry. The excellent FLAVOR has big caramel/toffee, vanilla, pipe tobacco, dark honey, port, molasses, and some candied dark fruit. Mildly sweet but far from cloying. Actually finishes quite smooth for being 13.4%. Delicious and supremely executed. (478, 875)

2011 bottle. Dark copper pour with a tan head. Aroma is of oak, raisins, dates, brown sugar, and bourbon. Flavor is big sweet candied dark fruits, oak, and molasses. Slightly warming finish from the abv but not overpowering. Tasty.

Draft at The Bier Stein, Eugene. Pours a medium brown, decent amount of tan head. Aroma Bourbon with a slightly nutty character, some sweetness, caramel. Body rich, full, boozy, finish way too much. Yikes! Maybe hotter than anything else Ive had. Shouldve sat on this longer, brewery.
Boozy alcohol in the nose. Pours an oily liquid amber with small head. Goes down with warm alcohol and brandy

Sampled at DLD 2014. It poured an almost black color with a small tan head. The aroma was of malt, caramel, vanilla, fruit and bourbon. The taste was of roasted malt, dark fruit, caramel, vanilla and bourbon.
Cloudy dark amber, no head. Aroma raisin, molasses. Flavor strong raisin, dried plum, caramel, vanilla. Body rich, sweet, subdued carbonation. Finish sweet, body rich, carbo subdued.

2013 bomber poured into a snifter @ 50 degrees a almost black with a thin head that disappeared quickly.
Aroma is rich. Licorice, coffee, dark fruit some booze.
Flavor is a syrup thick with malts. Picking up some chocolate here & plenty of cherry prune with some bourbon. Noticed the lack of "in your face" booziness. A brewer that makes a high ABV without immediate slap it in your face has my respect. 
On the palate is pretty much perfect for an English style. Sweet, subtle & so good.
Definitely in my top 5 of barleywine which include Sucaba & Abacabus.

2013 bottle poured into a snifter. Aroma of bourbon vanilla. Appearance is clear dark reddish brown almost black letting almost no light pass through it. Rich in flavor, vanilla, bourbon, liquorice, prune, and cherry with a slight hoppy bitter finish. This is a fantastic Barleywine in my top 5. Palate is slightly viscous going down very smooth. A sipper for sure as the 13.4% abv makes itself know as you drink this. This is dfinitely a bottle worth sharing. Added note ... try this with peanut butter or peanuts.

With several years of experience now behind me I now have the palate to appreciate this huge BW from Midnight Sun. Pours a cloudy copper from the 22 oz bomber, An aroma of licorice and an unknown essence. Slides smoothly across the palate and spreads a warmth that is very pleasant. This is a special experience to be savored and remembered. Way to go Midnight Sun.

My go to barleywine - gee I wonder why, oh yeah, its where I live.

The appearance had a fairly dark brown body with a half finger white foamy head that quickly dies to a film coating the top of the body. Lacing is there but a bit messy and all over the place.
The smell has a huge sweet aroma of roasted malt intricately combined within a molasses, vanilla, coffee-ish complexity, light caramel and a subdued alcohol note take a secondary place.
The taste is sweet through previously mentioned flavors, but yet balances through some bitter coffee notes. Light black licorice seems to come through in the flavoring, black licorice aftertaste but done nicely and not overbearing, dry finish.
The palate was a medium to heavy, more of a sipper than drinkability. Carbonation seems to be done very well for an English Barleywine and is pretty good to me.
Overall, what a nice English Barleywine that I would have again every winter.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2015 On tap at Barcade, Brooklyn. Murky brown like brown sugar syrup. Aroma is of a sweet dessert. Taste is sweet caramel, toffee, dates, but never cloying or overly sticky. Bourbon is in the mix but not the whole of the story; booze. Overall, nice Barleywine - very caramelly. 
Bottle from New York last year, drunk 14th April, 2015. Not much on the aroma, just a bit of marshmallow and oak. Taste is more complex this time - brown sugar, maple syrup, burnt caramel, bitter finish. Like sweet caramel sauce (4.1).

2011 Vintage bottle. 
Aroma has a moderate caramel and toffee with a faint roast character and moderate burnt toast. Moderate fruitiness with dark plum, fig and prune along with moderate raisin. Some alcohol spice. Medium light bourbon charger and light oak. 
Pours a dark, burnt amber with some brown hues with a small, somewhat thin tan head that recedes fairly quickly to the edges where it lingers a bit. Light lacing and fairly long legs. 
Flavor has a fairly strong malt character and light sweetness. Lots of dark toast, caramel, toffee along with some biscuit and cracker. Medium fruit notes of plum, fig, prune and raisin; surprisingly fruity for a barleywine. Moderately strong bourbon character with some light oak. Moderate bitterness and medium light oxidation. Moderate alcohol spice in the finish. 
Mouthfeel is medium full bodied with medium carbonation. Medium astringency and medium alcohol warmth. 
Overall an alright beer but it hasnt aged gracefully. Lots of dark fruit, astringency and faint soy sauce that seems to have been accentuated by oxidation. Lots of whiskey notes as well. The malt notes are a little odd.
Damn good barleywine. Pours medium brown. Good carbonation and mouthfeel. Barrel prominant but doesnt dominate. Good balance. Very smooth, hides alcohol well. One of my new faves.

Sometimes bourbon-barrel aging is over-the-top, meaning you wonder if the brewer would rather be making bourbon. Not so here. The bourbon is well suited to the barley wine style and at the right level to not overtake the awesome malt notes. Look forward to trying much more from Midnight Sun. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Solid. Syrupy sweet. Heavy on the malts. Big flavor, with a good infusion from the barreling. No booziness, which is amazing.

I guess the is the 2013 "Ale Aged in Bourbon Oak Barrels". Pours viscous deep brown with thin yellow head. Sweet aroma of caramel and toffee. Taste matches aroma with sweet caramel/toffee , some dark fruits, small amounts chocolate, bourbon, oak. Tiny bit of butterscotch but not the lingering butterscotch taste you get with bad beer. Thick palate with nice alcohol burn. Finish slight oaks and hops, booze. i didnt pick up much hops at all. Really nice beer,wish I had more.
Thanks Mike for the 2011 bottle. Really good traditional barleywine smells. Very good dark fruit flavors.
Amber brown colored, small head, good lace/retention. Aroma of wood, caramel, vanilla, bourbon, alcohol. Full bodied, sweet, light alcohol. Straightforward, big flavors, enjoyable.

2013 Bottle thanks to Rob. Pours a very brown with small creamy beige head. The aroma is strong booze, roast, candy sugar. Medium mouthfeel with light rich candy sugar, raisin, and nice boozy finish. Good.

2013 release. Nice murky brown reddish pour. Carmel, syrup and dark malt nose with bourbon and oak notes. Medium to full body. Rich caramel and vanilla flavors, not too much alcohol burn actually very sweet and mellow at this point. Beautiful bourbon flavors throughout. Best damn BA barley wine Ive ever had.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2014 Poured from a bomber (2014 vintage) with a muddled mahogany and a quickly dissipating head. Smells like oaky vanilla, biting spice, caramel, bourbon, earthy roots. Low carbonation with a nice slightly syrupy almost wort like body. Tastes like licking an oak tree oozing vanilla syrup and booze and bitter hops. Also smoked meat and spiced beef jerky. I feel like Midnight Suns beers have a distinct earthiness and vegetable root and mushroom quality that I just love and this beer is no different. This devil has been digging underground. I think this this beer is so unique and delicious and super underrated. Id pick it of Firestones Sucaba. It is that good. The only reason I dont rate it higher, is because Ive had it aged and it gets so much better.

Bottle 22oz. [2011 Vintage]
Pours dark burgundy with low beige head. Aroma is of caramel, alcohol, vegetal stuff, resin, malt. Taste is of caramel, sugar, roasted malt, booze, butterscotch. Palate: Full bodied. Overall: Malty, sweet. Good.

Bottle from a great trade. Thanks. This goes down as rating #1,001 after my #1,000 disappointment. No bottle date to speak of but pretty sure it is a 2013 bottle. Pours dark brown nearly black with a small khaki colored head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, caramel, nuts, rich chocolate. Flavor is big rich sweet chocolate caramel up front, then fades on to a medley of dark fruits, and finally bursts into a big vanilla oakiness that just longer on the palate for a long while. Lots going on here with many layers. Big thick rich mouthfeel with just enough carbonation to ensure it is not syrupy. Not too sweet with the oak showing through very strong to balance. Mmmmmm.

Bottle thanks to Shane! Pours a near clear deep amber with a light brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a great combination of caramel, sweet light fruits, sweet grains and vanilla backed by a bit of booze. Flavor starts with grains and bread that grow in sweetness and finishes with caramel and sweet bourbon.

22oz 2013 bottle that I had been saving for the right night. Pours a very dark brown with one thin ring of off white head. Nose is thick with caramel and brandy, woody, vanilla bean, malt, cookie dough, heavy butterscotch, red grape. Flavor is very solid, bitter, resinous, some fortified wine, butterscotch, lots of dried raisin, malt, a little maple, a touch salty. Thick, syrupy finish. 22oz is a lot for one man, but I did it and Im not ashamed.

Murky opaque reddish brown, thin beige head. Very sweet aroma of crystallized brown sugar, sticky caramel, ripened fig, dates, raisin, and apple. Fairly balanced bittersweet flavors, medium-bodied at first and ending on a lighter note. Smooth and rich, but not overly heavy. Moderate alcohol presence in the finish

Bottle shared by Tommy, 2011 vintage. Thanks a lot! Pour is brown with a thin head that leaves OK lacing. Aroma is of alcohol, candies and bourbon. Taste is sweet and syrupy with some light bourbon flavors. I believe I could pour that on some ice cream or crepes and it would be really decadent. Mouthfeel is sticky, finish is sweet. Alcohol is so well hidden it is really hard to believe it is in there. Really well made, quite happy to have been able to sample this one!

bottle shared by tom10101, thanks bro! pours clear light ruby with a small off-white head, little retention. woody oak-forward, bourbon vanilla, fruity malts - berries, some cherries, hint of acidity, very spicy, aged malts feeling - garbage-like, grass, pepper. moderate to low carbonation, medium body - oily, a bit sticky, although never cloying or boozy, warming fruity-spicy-grassy finish. nice but heavy on wood.

Bottle (22 oz). 2011 vintage. Thanks to heyta for this one! Slightly hazy dark copper with a small/medium beige head and little lacing. Aroma is of bourbon, caramel, fruits, wood, vanilla, sweetness. Surprisingly, its not overly boozy despite the high abv. Taste is moderately sweet with bourbon, caramel, fruits, vanilla, tobacco and wood. Warming alcohol. Full bodied. Moderate carbonation. Good Barley Wine. Quite complex. Not overly boozy. Excellent sipper!
Bottle. Pours black. Aroma is vanilla, oak, bourbon. Taste us the same. Smooth. Alcohol warming. Finish is nice.

Bottled 31JAN13
Pours really dark- like nearly stout. Tan foam and spotty lace
Smells sweet, boozy, nougat, vanilla...actually, this beer is a mess
Taste is sweet booze, vanillas, raisin, marshmallows. Full body with moderate on low carved and a dry, peeling finish. I wasnt happy last time and Im less impressed now.

Review 08MAR12
3.5/4.5/3.5/2.5/3.5-3.6
Vintage 2011, ABV 13.4%
Pours a dark amber body with fleeting tan head, leaving a sheet of the same. Caramel, vanilla, oak, bourbon, Brandy(?), seafoam, hints of leather and sherry oxidation. Flavor is similar to the nose, but less impressive and there is an alcoholic tinge to the finish. Thin bodied and low carb, the booze is evident on this one and leaves a burn. This is a good beer, but my favorite was the 08, sadly I didnt review back then, but I recall a fuller body and more refined character in the beer. As it stands, I would advise trying this beer, but not really seeking it out particularly hard, unless youre ChadQuest or other peeps that really dig the BA BWs.

Acquired in 2009 and saved for a special date. Rating No. 5,000 seemed special enough. This is the 2007 or earlier vintage. Brown pour with a tan head. The aroma is full of caramel malt, oak and brown sugar. The flavor has a ton of the same notes with some additions. I get a lot of oak, vanilla, maple, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, raisins and alcohol. Awesome. Medium to thick mouthfeel and medium carbonation. At six years old this beer was amazing. Happy I have a 2010 in the cellar to continue aging.

2007, thanks Bill / Mora2000! Ugly murky brown color leaves soapy tan suds on my glass. 

Smells of aged booze, liquified raisins, creamy caramel, and more. Taste improves on the above, adding boozy complexity, dark fruits, chocolate notes, butterscotch, damn tasty. This has aged like a champ; way better than fresh. Big fan.
bottle, pours imperal stout black color, no head. nice sweet overripe dark fruit nose, and alcohol. sweet, sugars, alcohol, warming, dark. yummy!

Thnx to smurf2055 
Pours black , grey fast fading grey foam 
Smell is bourbon and oaky , very sweet typical bw 
Taste is thick , buttery , sweet , some sugar . Very nice ! Thnx man !

Review from notes 2007 Bottle Shared by MrBarleywine.
Pours a deep copper color with a decent sized off white head that shows moderate retention. Aromas of dark caramelized sugar, dark pitted fruits, bits of wood, hints of rum and bourbon, light alcohol, no hop aromas. The flavor is sweet with dark sugars, light oak, light fruits, a solid hit of warming alcohol and a touch of earth. Medium to thick body with a moderate to light level of carbonation and a sweet almost sticky mouthfeel. One of my favorite barley wines, I only wish it were a little easier to obtain.

A: Dark Amber Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head, Mild Lacing

S: Bourbon, Maple Syrup

T: Maple, Bourbon

M: Average Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Sweet, Boozy

Overall, a decent barrel aged barley wine with some sweet, boozy finish.

22 ounce bottle from Timfoolery, aroma is whiskey and caramel, flavor is similar, boozy mouthfeel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This one poured a medium brown with a beige head. Aroma was big strong whiskey, chocolate, dark fruits, and toast. Flavor was whiskey soaked chocolate, sweeter dark fruits and a lightly choppy finish. Pretty great stuff.

Bottle @ Steves house. 2011 vintage. Pours a fairly clear, red orange appearance with a thin off white head. Quite spicy, very woody, raisin, toffee, dark fruity aroma. Big caramel, rich toffee, dark fruity, light chocolate, somewhat boozy, a bit oxidized flavor that actually a little bitterness on the finish. Easy to stick for the abv but not an elite barleywine in my opinion.

Pour out of 22 oz bottle, 2011 vintage thanks to Aaron! Dark reddish brown pour with thin off white head, aroma brought notes of big dark fruit, dark toffee, molasses, hints of caramel, nice figs, raisins, dark cherry, nice. Taste is a mix of dark fruits, figs, hints of fruit, lots of toffee, molasses, caramel, fig, dark cherry, finishing fairly sweet, nice bourbon and oak notes but the age has done pretty well on this.
07, 10, 11, 13. 13 is the darkest by far. 13 sweet toffee strong bourbon. None of these are blowing me away

Tap. Pours cloudy brown, small tan head, creamy with nice lacing. Malty aroma, caramel, toffee, oak, perhaps bourbon, but its not strong. Flavor is similar, light to medium sweet, not a lot of bitterness to back it up. Barrel notes are present but very muted, and not a lot of wood astringence. Well rounded, but a little thin on character as compared to the best. Medium plus body, creamy mouthfeel.

2010 vintage. Pours a rich copper color with a finger of eggshell foam. The nose is creamy toffee, dates, vanilla extract, whiskey and brown sugar. The mouthfeel has a nice smooth tight bubble and is a bit thinner and less chewy than expected from the nose. Great round soft sweetness on the front end that rolls into a whiskey oak toasted finish.
2013 Bottle. Amazing beer! Caramel, dark fruit, chocolate, whiskey, oak, and a ton of other notes that subtly develop over every sip. Wow...

Bottle at WWT III. Pours pitch black with a medium tanned head. Aroma has loads of bourbon, sweet, raisins, alcohol. Taste also has quite some bourbon, sweetness, roast, dark fruits and alcohol. Too sweet for me.
Bottle @ WWT III. Black colour with a tan head. Nose is roasted malt,s rye, oak and dark fruits, Flavour is roasted malts, dark fruits and candy sugar. Finish is fairly sweet and a bit dry.

66cl Bottle at WWT III. Deep dark brown colour, beige head. Aroma is quite sweet, pumpernickel, liquorice, molasses, chocolate, pipe tobacco. Flavour is a lot less sweet than expected, molasses, chocolate, roasted malts, toast, bourbon, berries, full and velvety mouthfeel, just packed with flavour. Full-bodied. Great, great stuff.
Bottle at WWT3. Dark pour. Beautiful aroma of bourbon, chocolate and coffee. Taste is full bodied with chocolate. Great balanced beer!

Bottle thnx to bytemesis, @ WWT III. Pours a pitch black beer with a small, tanned head on top. Aroma of licorice, malts, booze and loads of bourbon characters. Flavor is very sweet, alcoholic and malty. Very full bodied, awesome balance and this a great brew! Ripe red fruits and boozy characters are well present. Great brew!

Bottle at WWT3. Poured a dark mahogany with a glass hugging tan head and an oily consistency. The aroma is rich and alcoholic. The flavour is strong bitter with lots of alcohol liqourice and rich fruit on the palate. A super heart warming beer.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2013 Sampled from bottle @ WWT III. Opaque pitch black color, small beige head. Aroma of malts, lightly sweet, bourbon. Taste malts, roasted malts, alcohol, bourbon and some sweetness. Absolutely lovely beer. Full bodied, quite subtle carbonation. Lovely.
Bottle @ wwt. Aroma is thick molasse with rye, some liquorice and more. Flavour is thick liquorice molasses caramel and more. Lrab.

Bottle @ WWT3. Very dark brown pour. Aroma of bourbon, roasted, chocolate, coffee, malty and spicy. Flavor is huge full bodied, sweet chocolate, malty, roasted and alcoholic. Enormous beer, great balance.

66cl bottle sampled at wwt3. 
Thin tan head. Clear black pour. Sweet. Smooth brew. Great brew.

Pours really dark for a barley wine. Heavy aroma of dark fruit, molasses, and dark brown sugar. Taste is similar with a booze bite and a hint of bourbon and wood. Pretty decent stuff that packs a punch.

22 ounce bottle. Thanks Mike! Pours almost black with a small tan head. Aroma of malt, caramel, vanilla, fruit, and bourbon. Taste is roasted malt, dark fruit, caramel, vanilla, and bourbon. Very nice. Hides the 13.2 % pretty well.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2014 Bottle kindly shared by dennoman. Pours deep brown with red hue and small lingering head. Aroma of vanilla and bourbon, chocolate chip cookies. Medium body low carbo high on the alcohol. Taste of plums liquorice and oaky bourbon. Okay beer.
----
Re-rated after sample at Jeffos place, compared to Flossmoor barley wines. Way more refined and subtle. Fresh 2011-2012 bottle
Bottle. Clear dark amber beer with a small offwhite head. Sweet, malty, chocolate, vanilla and caramell aroma. Malty, salty, vanilla, caramell flavour with alcohol notes.

(bottle) hazy amber with a small brown head; faint aromas of caramel and dried fruit; subdued and balanced flavour with a long light sweet finish; bit unusual in subdued flavour for the type, still good

Pretty sure this was a bomber from 2007, happy to finally get to try this. Dark mahogany with a thin khaki head that disappears fairly quickly. Needed a bit of time to open up once it was poured into the glass but once it did the aroma was delicious - vanilla, sweet caramelize malts and brown sugar, booze is mellow and well integrated, a bit of balsalmic glazed figs. Mild carbonation, moderate+ body, goes does really easy, slight oxidization, sweet with a slight alcohol kick on the finish. Tasty.

Poured into a perfect pint. 2008 vintage.

4.0 A: Clear darker amber color. Aggressive pour yielded just one finger of light brown creamy/frothy head. Retention is okay given the ABV and a short ring of lacing is left.

4.5 S: Nose on this is divine. Perfect mix between the barrel and the beer. Bourbon is fruity, leathery, and lightly earthy. Oak and vanilla with no tannic astringency. The base offers a ton of caramel, moderate toffee, tobacco, raisin, dates, prunes, sugar plums, and apple. Sweet sugary maltiness, molasses, and some toastiness. Alcohol is non-existent.

3.5 T: Taste is a bit of a let down after experiencing the nose. Dont get me wrong, its still tasty, but the mouthfeel is a bit too thin, which causes issues in the taste. Basically, the taste isnt as potent as Id like. Same flavors as in the nose, just less intensity. Leathery bourbon, earthiness, and light fruits. Caramel, toffee, tobacco, raisin are strongest. Prunes, sugar plum, molasses, and toastiness next. Apple underneath. Moderately sweet with just a light booziness. Borderline 4.0.

3.0 M: Lighter medium to medium body. Good moderate carbonation, especially for a beer this old. Missing creaminess and body. If this were a bit thicker, the taste would be better too.

4.0 D: Its a good beer that just has one fatal flaw. Great flavors, but I need more maltiness when Im drinking a barleywine. Ill have to try this fresh sometime.

Serving type: bottle

Bottle sampled at Kurts Blarneywine tasting on 3/16/13. Dark brown in color with a medium tan head. Caramel and raisin nose with some fig, banana and roasted malt notes. Malty and chocolatey flavor with some caramel and fig before a dry finish.
La robustesse des malts se combinent parfaitement au bourbon, exactement mon type de vin dorge idéal.

Bottle shared during RBWG-JAX! Deep amber brown pour with a small khaki head. Rich BA aroma with fudge and coconut goodness on top of rich dark fruits, caramel, toffee, and more. Luxurious slightly sweet BA barleywine flavor to boot. Good stuff!

Bottle, 2013 vintage, 05/19/2013. Pours dark mahogany, dense off-white head settles to a nice crema on the surface, dense lacing around the glass. Aroma is vanilla caramel cream, toffee and dark grained bread, touch of chocolate, bourbon. Taste is caramel chocolate, vanilla fudge, raisin and fig, a bit of roast and hop bitterness,  bourbon finish. Full, creamy mouthfeel, surprisingly not overly heavy for the ABV. Delicious.
on tap at city beer 2013 vintage, pours a dark reddish brown. Smell is boozey  with bits of vanilla and plumb. Taste is butterscotch, vanilla and has a warm finish from the booze. Tasty.
On tap at city beer. Taste is lots of fig and tobacco. Has a very sweet finish. Lots of wood from the barrels

Black color, brown foam, moderate lacing. Brown sugar/molasses smell, buttery. Taste has similar notes with chocolate, a touch of coffee. Slight bitterness and alcohol warmth in the finish. Good beer, not sure what the hype is about.
22oz Bottle pours a black color without much head. Strong caramel flavors, lots of sweetness, and some spice flavors. Mellows as it has time to breath. A great beer.

A - Dark red-brown with a finger of frothy khaki colored head. Fades normal.

S - Sweet caramel and caramelized malts, brown sugar, oak, vanilla, whiskey, dark fruits, and some booze.

T - Sweet caramel and caramelized malts, oak, vanilla, whiskey, brown sugar, dark fruits, toasted coconut, and some booze.

M - Full bodied with moderate carbonation. Smooth with a warming and sweet finish.

D - Fantastic barrel aged barley wine. Great overall balance.

Not the religious experience I was expecting.  The aroma is very sweet, boozy, fruit, vanilla.  The appearance is deep red/brown, opaque, thin head.  The flavor is fruit, booze, candi sugar, vanilla.  Certainly an "English" BW in that hops are almost non-existent.  Thick in body, sweet, sticky mouthfeel.  I wanted to pour this on some pancakes.    The finish is hot, solvent like.  I really enjoyed this, just not as much as I thought I might.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2014 Bottle, 2013 vintage.  Aroma: mmm, Sucaba-like.  Chocolate, caramel, toffee, vanilla, bourbon, oak, roastiness.  Sexy as hell.  Damn.  Pours dark brown/ruby with small tan head that dissipates quickly.  Taste: Dark fruit -- raisin, date, fig -- caramel, roasty chocolate, so well-placed oxidation.  Holy wow, nice.  Mouthful of happiness, with just the right hint of bitterness.  Sweet and rich.  Viscous, velvety slick texture.  Full body, soft carbonation.  Warming alcohol in the finish, but alcohol amazingly well concealed for the ABV.  Overall:  this is simply stunning.  A fantastic beer, worth sipping and sharing with friends.

</br> </br> 2014 bottle. Tons of burnt caramel which dominates this - very sweet, steeped grains, soy sauce. Given how much I loved this before, its a disappointment this time around. Id give it a 3.7 based on pure enjoyment -- going to knock it down from 4.5 to reflect this. Im a little afraid to buy it again lest I need to knock it down more.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2013 2013 bomber from trade with michaelinwa.  Pours a murky dark brown color with slight mahogany tint.  Nice 1 finger head that lingers a bit.  Big butterscotch and bourbon aroma mixed with some sugary dark fruits and vanilla.  Taste is very boozy with nice rich flavors.  Moderate sweet but not syrupy like some barley wines.  The butterscotch, bourbon, vanilla, figs, and raisin flavors are blend well together.  Slight alcohol warming in the finish.  Overall, this is a little boozier than I usually like my barley wines but I still love it.  Top notch.
Pours a murky dark tea color with an evenly distributed tan lacing. Aroma consists of candied sugar, dark fruits, licorice, vanilla, cherry, booze and cinnamon. The alcohol is somewhat harsh.

Sample at the Blarney Wine tasting on 03/16/2013: The beer is a clear dark mahogany color with a medium off-white head that diminishes steadily. Partial rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt, hops and oak. Full-bodied with flavors of malt, oaky bourbon, vanilla and figs. The finish is rich and malty with a bourbon and raisin aftertaste. Very good Barley Wine all around.
Had on draft at the brewery. Raisin, bourbon, coconut, vanilla, malty, viscous. A very good beer.
Sampled at a bottleshare. Dark brown color, little khaki head. Little loose lace. Awesome vanilla, light roast, dark vinous flavor in the nose. Warm finish. Light bitter, some spice. Great stuff

Bomber to oversized snifter (2011 vintage; thanks timfoolery). Looks good; a fairly opaque amber with fluffy off-white lacing. Smells semi-sweet and boozy. Tastes like it smells, only better. The vanilla really comes through in the taste. Good on the palate too. Great beer.

Black pour, modest tan head that goes away quickly, fantastic aroma of ripe fruit, cherries, vanilla and booze. Taste is much like the aroma, though more subtle than I would have thought going into it, and the alcohol and barrel notes come in really strong. I like the flavor, but this is a pretty hot beer and I think it sort of detracts from the flavor. There also could be way more complexity to such a big beer, and the palate could be more substantial. Carbonation is moderate. Finish is also a little unidimensional of alcohol. Enjoyable enough, and warrants the score, but lacks refinement. Still, Id probably try it again. I would not cellar this, but maybe the alcohol in it could add interesting flavor with time.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2013 Amazing barleywine, almost more like an Imperial Stout/barleywine hybrid. Deep ruby/brown, almost black color with a remarkably syrupy, mouth-coating body. Flavors of bourbon, brandy, roasted dark chocolate, cappucino, cherries, plums, orange peel, toasted coconut, leather, tobacco, and spices.

Theres definitely a good deal of heat, but this only adds more complexity, in a catalyst sort of way. Sucaba WAS my favorite barleywine, but this flavor//texture monster eclipses it.

Bomber Bottle. Amber pour with medium off white head, nice lacing patterns in the glass. Aromas of vanilla, toffee, toast malt, rich dark fruits, and light hops. Flavor was much of the same with a sweet sticky booze mouthfeel. Got less boozed out as it warmed but still a tad much for my palate. Full bodied Barleywine.

Pours dark and murky amber with a decent sandy head. The aroma brings some sweet malts and even a bit of sweet syrup notes, nice. The flavor brings sweet malts and delicious developed yeast notes, being that the bottle is from 2007, toopppss!. The carbonation was right on still bringing a smooth body.

Alaskan Barleywine festival 
Appearance: Cloudy brown with a medium sized tan head and spotty lacing 
Aroma of toasted malts and brown sugar. Flavors of roasted malts, brown sugar and vanilla 
Nice and tasty.

Bottle at The Barley Wine Tasting, London - many thanks to Bruce! Pours hazy, ruby-gold with a large and sturdy off-white foam head. Nose of cherries and berries, wet leaves, grapes. Medium to big sweet flavor with sugary bread, some more berries, faint caramel and brown sugar. Full bodied with fine carbonation. Warming finish, some alcohol sting, fructose sugars, faint berry tang. Its good but lacks richness and complexity.

22oz bottle. 2011 vintage.

A: Red raspberry with brown hints. Very thin lacing. Grips the glass.

N: Tons of caramel and oak. Lots of toffee. Smoothly sweet like caramel being layered in a commercial. Smells like a fresh coffee cake with specks of brown sugar.

T: Very well blended. Has a distinct oakiness that lends peppercorn and vanilla. Caramel and toffee flavors are subtle. Raisins and licorice bitterness. Theres a pronounced hop presence/some pineapple.  Could use a little more sweetness, IMO, but I cant really knock the execution, either.

M: thinner than I might like, but it keeps the beer from being a choking hazard. Alcohol is really well hidden.

O: One of the best barleywines out there. Strong execution all around, and highly recommended. So smooth and complex.

2010 bottle.  Dark reddish brown pour with some head but quick to fade as is typical with the style.  Nose and taste are fairly similar in their sweet sticky caramel and toffee like flavors.  Wish it was a bit sweeter with some vanilla notes but since I tried this after Grey Monday it may have been there but just not noticeable coming off such a sweet beer.    

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle kindly shared by Austin and poured into a tulip.  Pours a copper color with a small beige head.  Nose is dark fruit, oak, vanilla.  Flavor follows with some bourbon, oak, vanilla, toffee.  Full-bodied, sticky mouthfeel.  Pretty good but not outstanding.
Sampled at an dsbls tasting.  Hazed brown with an off white ring.  Raisins in the aroma woth malts.  Raisiny flavor is fairly big.  Big malts.  A bit of heat. Nthis was very good.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2013 Bottle at home. 2010 vintage. Pours clear amber with a small offwhite head. Aroma is dark fruits, raisin, toffee, oak, whisky notes, ripe fruits. Flavor is raisin, plums, toffee, oak, ripe fruit, light alcohol notes. This is awesome.
Older vintage, it was slightly oxidized, still boozy, sweet, a bit undercarbed and viscous. Not my fav.

Courtesy of ksurkin. 2010 vintage consumed 11/30/12. Deep mahogany pour with garnet hints when held to the light. Very tight beige microfoam a la a finely crafted latte. Waves of vanilla, toffee, cherry pie crust, caramel, and raisinet in the nose lead to a flavor of beautiful oaken vanilla, figs, dates, rich caramel, and further iterations of sweet cherry pie. Hints of oxidation lead to sherry and port wine notes, but not in a detracting way. No alcohol detectable in the flavor or nose, but the beer is definitely warming on the way down. The palate is thick, rich, supple, succulent, and assertive with a very sweet body that finishes about as dry as a beer this massive can. This is likely my favorite Barleywine ever, and Ive had a few... There is just something about the feeling of coming inside from a 20 degree New England day after stacking wood, sitting in front of a roaring fire, and then quaffing this beer savoringly. Perhaps its partly the holistic experience that warrants such a high rating, but thats the spirit of Barleywine isnt it?

Bottle courtesy of rlgk. Pours hazy reddish brown with a thin beige head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace on the glass. Smell is sweet, malty and fruity with sweet dark bread, golden syrup, orange zest, grass, pine, caramel, alcohol, prunes, raisins, glue, rubber and hints of cereal. Taste is sweet and bitter with sweet dark bread, toasted cereal, salty liquorice candy, orange peal, resinous wood, pine, alcohol, lemon balm, parsley, gooseberries, vanilla fudge, moist soil, wet stone and golden syrup. Mouthfeel is round, herbal bitter, tiny boozy and medium to full bodied. Finish is slightly sweet and slightly bitter with sweet dark bread, gooseberries, toasted cereal, vanilla fudge, wet stone, resinous wood, moist soil and lemon balm.
Sampled at UCTS testing. Pours dark copper with a small brown head. Smells vanilla, figs and sweet roasted malt. Tastes burned roasted malt and abit sweet with a similar finish.

Sampled at USSkovde
Ruby red. No head. 
Broth-like aroma; vinous and some hair-salon. 
Sweet fruits in the flavour. Vinous. Light body.

Bottle at USA comes to Skövde. Amber/copper beer with a small beige head. Malty vinous aroma, caramel, raisins, dades, bread, oak and whisky. Malty oak flavor, hay, caramel, boozy, raisins, dades, caramel, smoked. A bit strange, not bad but a bit unclean.

Huge thanks to Eric (Holland) for the bottle. You made some fellow beer geeks very happy. 2011 vintage bottled the first week in February. 22 oz bomber served in a FW tulip.

A: Pours a very dark ruby color a light khaki head forming on the pour. It recedes to a thin film and ring that leave some splotchy lace behind.

S: Light whiskey and oak with some sweet, fruity esters and dark fruit. Caramelized malt sweetness as well.

T: Whiskey and light oaky body with a nice sweet malt body. Dark fruitiness with some light green hops. Minimal sweet berry flavor as well.

M: Medium bodied with a nice medium carbonation level with just a dash of heat on the finish.

O: The whiskey barrel was nicely integrated and a liked the sweetness it entailed. Very happy to have tried this guy.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-21-2012

Bottle. Pours a nice dark copper color with a beige head. Aroma is of filled with dark fruits, oak, vanilla, bourbon soaked raisins, cherries, caramel, toffee and earthy notes. The flavor follows the nose with nice amounts of barrel character, again lots of oak and vanilla, bourbon soaked raisins, caramel, toffee, earthy notes, cherries and nice sweet notes. The body is full with a silky and slightly sticky mouth feel. Overall a really nice BA Barley Wine.

Bottle 2011. Huge thanks to Peter and Jacop for sharing this with me. Hell to the yes!!
Pour slightly hazy reddish brown, with a small and deliciously looking off-white head. 
Aroma is of dark fruits, caramel, wood, cherries (delicious), vanilla (plenty of it). Slight boose on the nose, but only a little heat in the throat. Pretty darn tasty. 
The taste is pretty sweet, with some slight hoppy and bitter notes. Medium bodied, with a slightly fizzy carbonation. This is rather tasty, am glad these guys gave me a go at this.

Bottle @ THE Barley Wine Tasting. Cheers to Bruce for the pour! The appearance is deep, murky brown with a small off-white head. The nose is toffee, some cinnamon powder, some toffee. The taste is actually quite fruity, bouncy toffee, plenty of sweet malty  flavors. Spicy woody finish. Big body. Enjoyable, but not top dog in the illustrious group we collected.

2011 vintage.

Dark reddish brown in color. Very hazy. Little to no head. Aroma consists of malt. LOTS of malt. Its sweet and toffee like with some nutty, vanilla and oaky undertones. Theres no mistaking this for anything but a barleywine! Taste is fruity, malty, toffee, some vanilla oak and whiskey alcohol flavor. Very well balanced and not at all boozy or overly alcoholic. In fact, other than a mild throat warming youd be hard pressed to guess that the abv in this is above 10% (13.4%!!!). Carbonation is perfect for the style. A very solid english barleywine.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2012 Bottle, thanks to Bruce THE at Barley Wine Tasting, August 2012. It pours dark brown, with a thin off-white lace. The nose is damp leaf, toffee, light toasted coconut, sweet caramel, light roast and sweet, over-ripe fruit. The taste is toffee, ripe dark fruit, leaf, spice, earth, maple syrup, metallic aspect and underlying alcohol warmth, with a bitter-sweet finish. Full body, low carbonation and well balanced. An enjoyable sipping beer.

2008 vintage


A-- Poured a dark but clear amber. Settled a near black color. Somewhat black and somewhat brown. No ruby with this, just an odd but neat sort of color. One finger light brownish yellow head that had somewhat of a glow to it. Very neat looking. Head fell to film and stuck at film through drinking, leaving a yellow brown film at the bottom of the glass. 

S-- Whisky, oak, stewed plumbs, figs, old leather, tobacco, red wine. First time in a long time I thought I was smelling a wine. Excellent. 

T-- Whisky, oak, dark fruits, (started to get apricots), leather, tobacco, and port. Whisky and oak drop off and leave a combo of the leather, tobacco, fruits and port. Flavors changed and came in waves. 

M-- Thick and rich. Very chewy. Left tannins on my gums. Just warmth from the alcohol, it feels every bit the 13.4 % but hides it in the feel so very well. Well balanced and just plain decadent. 

O-- Slow sipper. Glad I shared this as would struggle on a whole bottle of this. Can not think of a barleywine that comes close to this in the complexity and depth that this had. First beer I have had in a long time that afterwards I just have an instant longing to have again. Unreal

Huge thanks to shadowane for sharing! 2011 vintage. 

Pours a dark amber, almost chestnut brown color with mahogany edges and a 1.5 finger, creamy off-while head that slowly settles into a lasting ring. Spotty lacing. 

Sweet, slightly boozy aroma with subtly integrated barrel presence.  Hints of toasted oak and spicy whiskey along with some vanilla and coconut.  Underneath characteristics of the base beer are evident with leathery malt, sweet toffee, dark fruit and caramel. 

On the fuller end of medium-bodied with a well integrated barrel character that doesnt overpower the elements of the base beer.  Some nice dry oak along with spicy/sweet whiskey, vanilla and coconut. Soft carbonation adds to the palate and the sweet and leathery notes from the base beer really come through. Hints of toffee, dark fruit, caramel and leathery malts with a slightly dry finish.  Subtle warmth in finish but overall the ABV is very well masked.  Lots of boozy flavor but not a lot of heat.  Cant believe that its 13.5%!  Really nice. A bit heavy on the barrel/whiskey presence but the characteristics of the base beer come through nicely.

Shared a bottle of this with Matt today. Thanks!

2008 vintage

A: Dark brown with crimson hues appearance and a one inch head. Initially, there is a sheet of lacing, but it fades after a few moments.

S: The aroma is fantastic. Sweet malts with dark fruits. No heat in the aroma. 13.4%?!?

T: Fabulous taste! Wow. This is my new favorite English Barleywine.
Very complex, with dark fruits and delicious malts.

M: 13.4% alcohol is completely hidden. Not sure how they did that.

D: Awesome. Highly drinkable. Best barleywine Ive had to date.

Bottle: Poured a thick chocolate colored brown with a thin off white head. Aroma is sweet caramel, fruit, and booze. Taste is dark fermented fruit with strong caramel malt, stick to the palate. Finishes with boozy warm alcohol. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

65cl, Vintage 2011, at 13.4%Vol, exclusive American brew, thx to Secret Santa!, complex brew, malty/woody and slightly alcoholic/fruity, not too heavy, yet very balanced, hazy, good head, very good brew, yet very expensive!, WOW!

22 ounce bottle shared by Gillard at his place, thanks Ryan, poured a dark cloudy brown color, with little carbonation (most likely due to it being a 3 year old bottle) with aromas of all raisins, dark fruit, and a touch of caramel.  Flavors follow suit, but raisin is the main flavor, not too big of a boozy bite either, rather enjoyable.

Bottle. Pour is a golden red, unusual for a typical barleywine. The aroma is huge with sweetness and alcohol. The taste is big upfront, but mellows pit throughout. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Location: Bottle shared by NickD717, 6/2/12


Aroma: It has a fairly complex nose with sweet malts, caramel, earth, fruits, wood, and spice

Appearance: This one pours a mahogany brown color with a small head atop it

Flavor: The taste has a rich malty flavor with some nice really complexity, and minimal bitterness

Palate: The body is full and on-style, with a rich mouthfeel, and a good bit of heat (thats not overpowering)

Overall Impression: 
Thanks for flying this one across the counrty Nick!  This beer was really really good!  I quite enjoyed drinking this one.  I hope Midnight Sun gets distributed out east some time soon!

Pours amber colored, no head, and minimal carbonation.  Aroma is apricot, sugar, malt.  Very sweet yet not sugary, its fruity and smooth to the palate.  Slight oakyness, I only had a small sample but didnt detect too much in the barrel aging.  Finish is moderate and sweet.  Delicious.

Location/Date:2011 Bottle on June 2nd, 2012 brought by nickd717.
Appearance: Pours a darker copper. 
Aroma: Aroma is of caramel, booze and wood.
Taste: Light medium bitterness, strong boozy malt backbone, hint of wood.
Palate:Medium body, slick, lingering aftertaste.
Summary: First off, thanks Nick! I really enjoyed this barleywine, though at times it seemed a bit boozy(yes I know barleywines are high alcohol) for me.

Shared a 2011 bottle with friends. Poured a red, semi-translucent color with a very wispy white head. Aroma was sweet toffee malts, with a touch of alcohol, vanilla, caramel. Flavor was sweet caramels, vanilla, and a ton of toffee, candy-filled brew.

2011 bottle shared by BuckeyeBoy. Nose of caramel, minerals, chocolate, vanilla. Not all that fragrant, though. Almost black with lace. Flavor of vanilla, bourbon, caramel; sweet and tasty, with apple. Not in perfect condition, I think, maybe a problem in bottling. Decent, but nothing like expected.

25th August 200910.0%. Opaque dark brown beer cloudy beer. Semi soft and semi dry palate. Rich aged tasting malt, hints of chocolate. Fairly spririty and brandyish. Some underlying and subtle dark fruits. Finishes semi dry and with aniseed. All joins up very well in to a rich and flavoursome barleywine. A little bitter bubblegum in the finish.
Sampled at Casanovas.  Delicious.  Very sweet, flavorful, and full of awesomeness.

2005 Batch(yep, marked 11/05 on side of bottle, 1st bottled):
A: Poured a golden copper color hybrid with almost a small white cap. 

S: Nose is toffee, some bourbon, toffee and caramel

T: Earthy and woody with light caramel and toffee. I felt some of the darker fruits faded, booze was still a bit sharp 

M: Mouthfeel is big bodied, lower carbonation

O: Good
///
2007 Batch:
Poured a sluggish copper color with almost no head at all. Nose is caramel, dried fruits, brown sugar candied fruits, vanilla and a very light hint of oak and bourbon. Yeah..all of this from the nose. Taste followed suit. Taste is biiig malts up front. Lots of brown sugar, candied fruit, fruits, with vanilla, oak and bourbon on the finish. Mouthfeel is nice, thick and coating. Sooo drinkable and the mouthfeel is great.
///
2010 batch. Not amongst the best. Demoted this year due to thinner mouthfeel, cardboard smell on nose and less flavor than I recall.

bomber from the brewpub. Poured a  chesnut brown color with a thin light brown head. Aroma of brown sugar, plum, rasins and a touch of vanilla. Moderately sweet, some caramel, notes of cherry with just a touch of smoke. A bit of toast, and a big vanilla flavor in the finish. Great stuff.

Bottle courtesy of bauermj.  Brilliant garnet with thin yellow head.  Light whiskey and oak, dark cherry, toffee, toasted malt, and a hint of booze.  Flavor is smooth whiskey, dark cherry, toffee, caramel, and light molasses.  Not cloying and without booze flavor - smooth all the way.  Crisp finish with some caramel, tart dark cherry, whiskey.  World class.

650 ml bottle.  2011 vintage.  Pours a golden copper with a small tan head that settles to a ring and leaves a decent amount of lacing on the glass.  The aroma is big coconut, some brandy and red wine, bourbon, vanilla, and caramel.  The initial taste is sweet with coconut and caramel.  There is also brandy, oak, bourbon, and toffee.  The finish has some light alcohol.  Full bodied but not syrupy.  Low carbonation.  Great beer.  Lots of flavors going on and everything comes together quite nicely.

Pours dark ruby to mahogany with almost no head. Smell is pungent, deep red fruits, intense citrus and candy sugar. Taste is very well balanced, a bit boozy, but lots of red fruit, tropical fruit, and sweetness. Taste is velvet. Very nice barleywine.

(22oz bomber thanks to cfh64 at Bluebonnet) clearish brown/orange with a little bit of tan head. Nose of rich bourbon, caramel, raisins, pretty nice smelling barley wine. Taste is a bit alcoholic, very light hops, caramel, some whiskey, and quite woody. I had high hopes for this and it didnt quite live up. I imagine that with some age, it would be considerably better.

One of the best Barleywines and best overall beers Ive ever had. Deep amber color with a thick white head. Soaring aromatics of stone fruit and sweet malt. Full bodied with a thick, sticky texture, caramel and toffee and a lingering whiskey finish.
Bottle. Brown pour with tan head.  Nutty and fruit like aroma with a firm malt backbone. No hop presence, malty flavor tones with a touch of oxidation.

Clear amber, frothy beige head. Aroma of dark fruit, tobacco, lots of toasty malt, nutty, wet leaf, earthy, some leather. Taste is sweet, but not overly so, lots of bready malt, toasted, some vanilla.Very well balanced, I wish more BWs were like this. This is not the case of a heavily hopped BW, where it may as well be a DIPA.
2011 Vintage has 13.4 ABV, 20 IBU, and 31 deg Plato. This is a super heavy, buttery ale. Tastes like a whiskey-beer hybrid. Clear caramel color.

From notes.

The beer itself is a full brown color, although it is somewhat transparent.  A small off-white head fades to a ring and a swirl of a thin film on top.

The aroma has a bit of ethyl alcohol that is noticeable right away.  Brown sugar, caramel, toffee, and a bit of earthy spice come into the nose.

Arctic Devil is definitely sweet up front, but ends up being nicely balanced.  Brown sugar is the most prominent sweet flavor.  Sweet caramel is also noticeable, and there is some full grainy notes.  A bit of peat and spice come in the middle, with a light general bitterness that accompanies a bit of an alcohol presence at the end.  

Surprisingly, this has kind of a light body for the style and feels a little watery.  The carbonation is on the light side and is a little creamy.

This clearly does not drink like 13.4%, but there is an ethyl alcohol presence that is a bit unappealing at this point.  Some age might improve this.  The light mouthfeel will most likely not change.

Thanks to Carleton for the pour.  Its clear brown with a circle of white foam.  Nose is subtle bourbon, vanilla, malt.  Taste follows the nose - delicious, extremely well balanced.  Malts, bourbon and a bit of vanilla.  Smooth.  Palate is nice - lightly carbed and medium bodied.  Excellent BA Barleywine.

Bottle provided by Carleton, poured into a Jackie Os snifter. A clear mahogany, deep ruby brown in color. A half fingers worth of head on the pour,  some gentle lace as it settles.  Nose is really nice, heavy on the caramel, vanilla, oak, and malt....balanced really well.  Flavor is caramel, dark fruit (raisin), vanilla, wood, and malt.  Palate is smooth with low carbonation, decent amount of booziness. Really nice english barleywine, one of the best.  Cant wait to finally let this age for awhile.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2015 P: Looks like a filthy mutherfucker. Its brown, orange, with a touch of burgundy. Nothing to see through on this one, with almost no head appearing. S: Oak, molasses. cherry and caramel are nicely introduced followed up by a bit of alcohol, maple syrup and chocolate. T: Caramel, cherries, oak, chocolate and a hint of bourbon. there is a touch of alcohol bu no warmth and is rather easy to drink. It s big on dark fruit but goes well with the the oak and chocolate/molasses flavors. M: Its a bit heavy, I dont feel much carbonation and almost drinks like a spirit. O: A great BW, happy to see this one on shelfs.

Bomber into a snifter.  Reddish brown pour with an off white head.  Aroma of red wine, caramel malt, toffee and bourbon.  Flavor is big malt, oak, dark fruit, red wine/port, caramel and light bourbon/booze.  Full body with soft carbonation.  The multi barrel treatment was nice for a change of pace.

22 oz. bottle from the brewery. Dark coppery brown color, with a somewhat amber, almost light-ruby hue. This has a wispy head, and a decent head sits around the circumference of the glass.Coconut, vanilla, and whiskey are coming together nicely, and providing a most excellent aroma. This is quite pungent and nice. Wow, for the ABV, its not that hot at all. It definitely providers a light warmth, but again, its not very hot. This has a wonderful whiskey, coconut, vanilla, and maple syrup flavor. This is very good, and Im having the perfect time in Alaska, hanging out after an 11 hour shift, in my hotel, sippin on this. This has a decent body, considering its viscosity.

22 oz bomber picked up at Ledgers a year or so ago. Split with buds while watching the Broncos implode. Reddish brown pour with a light tan head. Aromas of oak, caramel, dark fruit and port wine. Flavors of molasses, sweet figs, and vanilla wafers upfront with some whiskey influence on the backside. Smooth and creamy palate with loads of malty sweetness on the finish.  Pretty nice overall and a tasty BW.

Botte from the Bier Stein in Eugene, OR. Shared this bottle with Timfoolery and it was Awesome!! One of the best beers Ive ever had. Poured a brown color. Flavor was so complex, with a hint of bubble gum, carmel and too many others to describe. I need to have this beer again.

Bottle from The Beer Stein in Eugene from 2008.  This barleywine poured used-dishwater brown, but it was one of the best tasting beers Ive ever had. Almost a bubble-gummy, caramel type taste and very full as well. Just amazing complexity and extremely clean palate. Aged beautifully. Amazing beer!
This was a great Barley Wine. the woody characteristic is the most impressive thing along with the grape/nutty/ herby quality
Dark brown with a tiny tan head. Fruity and malty notes. Malt, fruit ( plums 9 and licorice. Full body with along, well balanced finish.

Bottle, 2010 vintage.  Reddish brown pour with an off white head.  Aromas of dark fruit and booze.  Huge caramel malt, port, plums, raisins, maybe a little cabernet in there also.  An interesting mix.....

2010 vintage.  A beer Ive wanted to try for a long time now.  Got a bottle of this a little while back but waited until now to crack it.  The pour is a deep amber-brown color with a tan head that settles as a patchy layer.  The aroma shows a mix of bourbon, plums, dates, toffee, caramel, brown sugar, and after all that a slight whiff of alcohol fumes.  Really nice.  The flavors are smooth and warming going down but perhaps not quite as impressive as the aroma.  Sweet candy-like flavors kick it off of dark fruit, caramel, and brown sugar.  This gets slightly toasty and boozy in the finish with more caramel.  Bourbon and wood is consistent throughout and gives this some nice depth and added flavor.  The carbonation is good.  Never does it seem too sweet.  There are barleywines I like better but if someone said that this was the standard for a barrel-aged barleywine I wouldnt argue much.  Nice depth, properly carbed, and the bourbon is plenty noticeable but not so strong to over power everything else going on.  Nice stuff.  And as a side note, I probably wouldnt want to age it too much longer than this.

First things first. Im going to want to try this one fresh.  This sample was from 2008 and as such may have passed its prime.  Pours clean rich coppery brown with one finger of sandstone head.
